docs.lead_paragraph: Practicing yoga may be one way to prevent middle-aged spread, according to the findings of a new study. Although the connection appears to be indirect, yoga practitioners are apparently able to avoid -- or at least minimize -- the one-pound-a-year of gained weight that most people endure between the ages of 45 and 55.

headline.main: Yoga May Help Minimize Weight Gain in Middle Age

docs.snippet: According to a new study, yoga practitioners may be able to avoid the one-pound-a-year of gained weight that most people endure between the ages of 45 and 55.

docs.lead_paragraph: Cigarette smoking and being exposed to secondhand smoke during pregnancy are equally likely to cause permanent genetic mutations in the fetus, a new report concludes. Dr. Stephen G. Grant, an associate professor of environmental and occupational health at the University of Pittsburgh, found that babies born to active smokers, to women who were exposed to secondary smoke during pregnancy and to women who quit smoking when they found out they were pregnant, all had similar and significant increases in gene mutations. The mutations were found by examining umbilical cord blood.

headline.main: Firsthand or Secondhand, Smoke Imperils Fetus

docs.snippet: Cigarette smoking and being exposed to secondhand smoke during pregnancy are equally likely to cause permanent genetic mutations in the fetus, a new report concludes.

docs.lead_paragraph: ''I wonder if patient could tolerate such a procedure emotionally,'' wrote a doctor about Mrs. E., a 44-year-old breast cancer patient being considered for a last-ditch brain operation called a hypophysectomy. ''I believe she stands a very real chance of another remission by hypophysectomy,'' wrote one of his colleagues.

headline.main: Rescued From Dustbin, Paper Medical Record Tells Its Tale

docs.snippet: Physicians' notes can teach us a great deal about the ordinary, and sometimes unexpected, events encountered by patients in the past.

docs.lead_paragraph: Past the five-foot-tall tanks of nitrogen gas, through a narrow, snaking hallway, behind double doors, just past the safety shower, they convene on the 10th floor of a building in Manhattan. They await an outbreak of smallpox or botulism, or nerve gas in the subway, perhaps a dirty bomb going off in Midtown. They are a creative bunch: well-educated, high-ranking, American. They are also dentists.

headline.main: Dentists Prepare to Be on Front Line of Civil Defense

docs.snippet: Dr. Dianne Rekow wants dentists to be first responders in times of crisis.

docs.lead_paragraph: Older and cheaper medicines work just as well as newer and more expensive drugs for relieving chronic pain caused by shingles, a review of 35 controlled randomized trials has found. The pain, called postherpetic neuralgia or PHN, occurs in about 10 to 25 percent of patients who get shingles. The condition is a result of nerve damage from the reactivated chickenpox virus -- called herpes zoster -- that causes shingles. It can last for months or even years.

headline.main: For Shingles Pain, Older Drugs May Work Fine

docs.snippet: Older and cheaper medicines work just as well as newer and more expensive drugs for relieving chronic pain caused by shingles, a review of 35 controlled randomized trials has found.

docs.lead_paragraph: The five Priore children were kicking, pinching and screaming at one another on television. The decibel level rose even further when Joe Priore, their father, shouted for them to stop and then proceeded to spank them, assembly-line style. ''The screaming, the yelling -- this is not a happy home,'' said Nina Priore, their mother, her hand shaking.

headline.main: Those Televised Supernannies May Be Just a Bit Too Super

docs.snippet: Parenting makeovers are popular among parents, but pediatricians and other child development experts say they are only partly rooted in reality.

multimedia.credit: Pediatricians and other child development experts say that reality shows like "Supernanny" are only partly rooted in reality.
multimedia.caption: Just a Bit Too Super

legacy.MultimediaSummary1: Pediatricians and other child development experts say that reality shows like "Supernanny" are only partly rooted in reality.

docs.lead_paragraph: People who suffer from chronic fatigue syndrome sometimes have trouble persuading their doctors that they have a real disease because its symptoms are so vague and their cause so elusive. Now a new study offers convincing evidence that patients with the syndrome, often referred to as C.F.S., have abnormalities in gene expression in their blood. The report appears in the August issue of The Journal of Clinical Pathology.
docs.snippet: A new study offers convincing evidence that patients with chronic fatigue syndrome have abnormalities in gene expression in their blood.

docs.lead_paragraph: On a computer screen hovers a three-dimensional image, the face of a boy with a cleft lip and palate. Using a mouse, a visitor to New York University's Virtual Surgery Research Laboratory can navigate through the boy's mouth, as if it were a landscape in a video game, passing under and through brightly colored layers of tissue, muscle and cartilage. Patches of transparency highlight underlying ivory bone.
docs.snippet: A simulation will eventually allow surgeons, medical residents and students to practice cleft lip and palate surgery in real time, in a 3-D environment.

docs.lead_paragraph: People whose net worth is over $70,000, the median in the United States, are 30 percent less likely than poorer people to feel pain at the end of their lives, a difference that persists even when controlling for age and severity of illness, a new study shows. The findings, which appear in the August issue of The Journal of Palliative Medicine, used information on more than 2,600 adults over 70 who died from 1993 to 1998. The researchers interviewed proxies, usually surviving spouses, to gather information about pain, depression, delirium and difficulties in breathing or eating at life's end.

headline.main: Wealth Is Likely to Mean Less Pain at Life's End

docs.snippet: People whose net worth is over $70,000, the median in the United States, are 30 percent less likely than poorer people to feel pain at the end of their lives.

docs.lead_paragraph: In America even a vitamin can become an instant celebrity with its own die-hard fan base and publicity machine. Vitamin E shot to fame in the early 1990's, after two large survey studies noted that male and female health professionals who said they took a supplement of up to 400 international units of the vitamin every day seemed to go on to develop fewer cases of heart disease or cancer than their peers who were not taking the supplement. The number of Americans, cardiologists included, who gulped daily capsules of vitamin E suddenly surged, from relatively few in 1990 to an estimated 23 million by 2000, according to an analysis published last month by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

headline.main: Vitamin E Fails to Deliver on Early Promise

docs.snippet: Even some scientists and health advisory groups who still have high hopes for Vitamin E as it occurs naturally have begun to pan the pills.
